> On 2010-01-19 13.05, Jan Algermissen wrote:
> >> I've been writing my a=
pp using a Java Swing client, and a server.=20
> The
> >> client asks for data in JSON-format from the server using a=20
> RESTful URL
> >> structure, and present it in the UI. All is well.
> >
>=
 > What do you mean by "RESTful URL structure"?
>
> A URL structure that re=
presents resources that can return state and
> perform actions on them.
>
>=
 >> In my situation, where the client just gets
> >> JSON-data, it seems to=
 me that I have to extend my usage of JSON=20
> so that
> >> I can get both the data to view, and a list of what actions=
 the=20
> client
> >> is allowed to perform, and then enable/disable UI elements=
=20
> accordingly.
> >
> > You should include Authentication information with =
the request and
> > determine on that basis what JSON to return. The JSON s=
hould drive=20
> the
> > UI with regard to the available actions (=3D=3Dnext possible=20
> transitions in
> > the application by the user through your UI).
>
> Tha=
t was the idea. I was just curious how others have formatted their
> JSON (=
if anyone has done it at all) to include such action info.
>
> >> Something=
 like this would be sent from the server:
> >> {"commands":["cmd1","cmd2],"=
data":{"foo":"bar"}}
> >
> > Well, maybe - if you think of 'cmd' in terms o=
f 'next transition'.=20
> If
> > you UI reacts on the cmds received that would be good.
>
> That's=
 the idea. We could also replace "cmd1" with URL's instead, so
> that the c=
lient doesn't have to generate URL's, but then we need more
> info to be se=
nt, similar to <a>'s (rel+href attributes).
>
> >> With the above I can bot=
h get the data I need to show, and know=20
> what the
> >> user is allowed to do with it.
> >
> > I think that is ok,=
 if you context prevents simpler solutions=20
> (e.g. use
> > HTML+browser in the first place).
>
> Yeah, that is not an=
 option. We need the more powerful UI features of
> Swing, and also want to=
 be able to connect to several servers at=20
> once in
> the UI.
>
hi Richard,

You could go a firefox plugin (or simil=
ar) - that'll get you round the=20
'several servers at once' issue, but, doesn't help with the lack of=20
powerful UI features - although nowadays I find that many of the=20
things which the browser environment enables - and easily too! - make=20
it better than swing ...

Roger

>
> /Rickard
>
>
